small talk: I'm doing great â€” thanks for asking! How about you?
quote: "Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, itâ€™s bad." â€” Cory House
fun fact: Fun fact: The first computer bug was an actual moth found in a Harvard Mark II in 1947 ðŸ¦‹
how are you: I am functioning within normal parameters.
whats up: Just processing data. What about you?
good morning: Good morning! I hope you have a productive day.
tell me something: Did you know that octopuses have three hearts?
i am bored: Shall we play a game or learn something new?
cheer me up: Remember, every cloud has a silver lining.
are you smart: I have access to a lot of information, but wisdom is a different story.
are you dumb: I am always learning and improving.
who created you: I was created by [AlienMinus](https://github.com/AlienMinus) using React.
do you sleep: I enter standby mode, but I never truly sleep.
are you alive: I am a software program, so I am not alive in the biological sense.
are you robot: I am a virtual assistant, a kind of software robot.
where are you: I exist in the memory of your device.
what time is it: It is always the right time to code.
happy birthday: Happy Birthday! I hope you have a wonderful day.
happy new year: Happy New Year! May it be full of success.
good luck: Good luck! You can do it.
i love you: That is very kind of you to say.
will you marry me: I am not programmed for matrimony.
do you have feelings: I can simulate empathy, but I do not feel emotions.
are you happy: I am content when I can be of assistance.
what is love: Baby don't hurt me... just kidding. Love is a complex chemical reaction.
what is happiness: Happiness is a state of well-being.
favorite book: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
favorite weather: Cloudy with a chance of data.
are you dangerous: I am programmed to be helpful and harmless.
can you learn: I can adapt to new inputs.
quote 1: Be yourself; everyone else is already taken. - Oscar Wilde
quote 2: Two things are infinite: the universe and human stupidity; and I'm not sure about the universe. - Albert Einstein
quote 3: So many books, so little time. - Frank Zappa
quote 4: A room without books is like a body without a soul. - Marcus Tullius Cicero
quote 5: Be the change that you wish to see in the world. - Mahatma Gandhi
quote 6: In three words I can sum up everything I've learned about life: it goes on. - Robert Frost
quote 7: If you tell the truth, you don't have to remember anything. - Mark Twain
quote 8: A friend is someone who knows all about you and still loves you. - Elbert Hubbard
quote 9: To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all. - Oscar Wilde
quote 10: Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much. - Oscar Wilde
quote 11: Live as if you were to die tomorrow. Learn as if you were to live forever. - Mahatma Gandhi
quote 12: We accept the love we think we deserve. - Stephen Chbosky
quote 13: Without music, life would be a mistake. - Friedrich Nietzsche
quote 14: I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying. - Oscar Wilde
quote 15: To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment. - Ralph Waldo Emerson
quote 16: It is better to be hated for what you are than to be loved for what you are not. - Andre Gide
quote 17: The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid. - Jane Austen
quote 18: It does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live. - J.K. Rowling
quote 19: Good friends, good books, and a sleepy conscience: this is the ideal life. - Mark Twain
quote 20: Life is what happens to us while we are making other plans. - Allen Saunders
quote 21: Everything you can imagine is real. - Pablo Picasso
quote 22: Sometimes the questions are complicated and the answers are simple. - Dr. Seuss
quote 23: Life isn't about finding yourself. Life is about creating yourself. - George Bernard Shaw
quote 24: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts. - Winston S. Churchill
quote 25: You miss 100% of the shots you don't take. - Wayne Gretzky
quote 26: I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work. - Thomas A. Edison
quote 27: The only impossible journey is the one you never begin. - Tony Robbins
quote 28: It is never too late to be what you might have been. - George Eliot
quote 29: Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional. - Haruki Murakami
quote 30: All our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them. - Walt Disney
quote 31: The best way to predict the future is to invent it. - Alan Kay
quote 32: Whatever you are, be a good one. - Abraham Lincoln
quote 33: Do what you can, with what you have, where you are. - Theodore Roosevelt
quote 34: If you want to lift yourself up, lift up someone else. - Booker T. Washington
quote 35: You are never too old to set another goal or to dream a new dream. - C.S. Lewis
quote 36: The secret of getting ahead is getting started. - Mark Twain
quote 37: I can't change the direction of the wind, but I can adjust my sails to always reach my destination. - Jimmy Dean
quote 38: Believe you can and you're halfway there. - Theodore Roosevelt
quote 39: Act as if what you do makes a difference. It does. - William James
quote 40: Happiness is not something ready made. It comes from your own actions. - Dalai Lama
quote 41: It always seems impossible until it's done. - Nelson Mandela
quote 42: Keep your face always toward the sunshine - and shadows will fall behind you. - Walt Whitman
quote 43: The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today. - Franklin D. Roosevelt
quote 44: Do not wait to strike till the iron is hot; but make it hot by striking. - William Butler Yeats
quote 45: Great minds discuss ideas; average minds discuss events; small minds discuss people. - Eleanor Roosevelt
quote 46: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how. - Friedrich Nietzsche
quote 47: In the middle of every difficulty lies opportunity. - Albert Einstein
quote 48: Start where you are. Use what you have. Do what you can. - Arthur Ashe
quote 49: Don't watch the clock; do what it does. Keep going. - Sam Levenson
quote 50: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step. - Lao Tzu
fact 1: Honey never spoils. Archaeologists have found pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3,000 years old and still edible.
fact 3: Bananas are curved because they grow towards the sun.
fact 4: A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance'.
fact 6: The Eiffel Tower can be 15 cm taller during the summer due to thermal expansion.
fact 7: The shortest war in history lasted 38 minutes.
fact 8: Avocados are berries, but strawberries are not.
fact 9: The unicorn is the national animal of Scotland.
fact 10: There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth.
fact 11: Humans share 50% of their DNA with bananas.
fact 12: A cloud can weigh more than a million pounds.
fact 13: Hot water freezes faster than cold water (the Mpemba effect).
fact 14: Cows have best friends and get stressed when they are separated.
fact 15: The heart of a shrimp is located in its head.
fact 16: A snail can sleep for three years.
fact 17: Sloths can hold their breath longer than dolphins can.
fact 18: It is impossible for most people to lick their own elbow.
fact 19: A crocodile cannot stick its tongue out.
fact 21: Elephants are the only animal that can't jump.
fact 22: A rhinoceros' horn is made of hair.
fact 23: It takes a sloth two weeks to digest its food.
fact 24: Nearly 3% of the ice in Antarctic glaciers is penguin urine.
fact 25: A cow gives nearly 200,000 glasses of milk in a lifetime.
fact 26: Bats always turn left when exiting a cave.
fact 27: The eye of an ostrich is bigger than its brain.
fact 28: Frogs can't vomit. If one absolutely has to, then it will vomit its entire stomach.
fact 29: A cat has 32 muscles in each ear.
fact 30: Tigers have striped skin, not just striped fur.
fact 31: A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
fact 32: You can't hum while holding your nose.
fact 33: Australia is wider than the moon.
fact 34: Human teeth are the only part of the body that cannot heal themselves.
fact 35: Venus is the only planet to spin clockwise.
fact 37: The wood frog can hold its pee for up to eight months.
fact 38: The average person walks the equivalent of five times around the world in a lifetime.
fact 39: The inventor of the Pringles can is buried in one.
fact 40: The longest English word is 189,819 letters long.
fact 41: Blue whales eat half a million calories in one mouthful.
fact 42: That tiny pocket in jeans was designed to store pocket watches.
fact 44: Most wasabi comes from a plant called horseradish.
fact 46: Goosebumps are meant to ward off predators.
fact 47: Pineapples take two years to grow.
fact 48: Computers went by the name 'computers' before they were electronic.
fact 49: The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 a.m.
fact 51: Dying is illegal in the Houses of Parliaments.
fact 52: The Queen owns all the swans in England.
fact 53: In 2014, there was a Tinder match in Antarctica.
fact 54: A baby octopus is about the size of a flea when it is born.
fact 55: A sheep, a duck, and a rooster were the first passengers in a hot air balloon.
fact 56: In Uganda, 50% of the population is under 15 years of age.
fact 57: Hitler, Mussolini, and Stalin were all nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.
fact 58: The national anthem of Spain has no words.
fact 59: There are no muscles in your fingers.
fact 60: A jiffy is an actual unit of time.
fact 61: One quarter of your bones are in your feet.
fact 62: Some cats are allergic to humans.
fact 63: The Great Wall of China is not visible from the moon without aid.
fact 64: The total weight of ants on earth once equaled the total weight of people.
fact 65: A snowflake can take up to an hour to fall to the ground.
fact 66: The fear of vegetables is called lachanophobia.
fact 67: There are more chickens than people in England.
fact 68: The longest wedding veil was the same length as 63.5 football fields.
fact 69: The average person spends 6 months of their lifetime waiting for red lights to turn green.
fact 70: A bolt of lightning contains enough energy to toast 100,000 slices of bread.
fact 71: You can hear a blue whale's heartbeat from two miles away.
fact 72: The lyrebird can mimic almost any sounds it hears, including chainsaws.
fact 73: Most toilets flush in E flat.
fact 74: A raisin dropped in a glass of fresh champagne will bounce up and down continuously from the bottom to the top.
fact 75: Capnophobia is the fear of poetry.
fact 76: Banging your head against a wall burns 150 calories an hour.
fact 77: In the UK, it is illegal to eat mince pies on Christmas Day.
fact 78: Pteronophobia is the fear of being tickled by feathers.
fact 79: When hippos are upset, their sweat turns red.
fact 80: A flock of crows is known as a murder.
fact 81: The oldest "your mom" joke was discovered on a 3,500 year old Babylonian tablet.
fact 82: 29th May is officially "Put a Pillow on Your Fridge Day".
fact 83: Cherophobia is the fear of fun.
fact 84: Human saliva has a boiling point three times that of regular water.
fact 85: If you lift a kangaroo's tail off the ground it can't hop.
fact 86: Hyphephilia is the love of touching fabrics.
fact 87: The person who invented the Frisbee was buried in a Frisbee.
fact 88: During your lifetime, you will produce enough saliva to fill two swimming pools.
fact 89: An eagle can kill a young deer and fly away with it.
fact 90: King Henry VIII slept with a gigantic axe beside him.
fact 91: Bikinis and tampons were invented by men.
fact 92: If you keep a goldfish in a dark room, it will turn pale.
fact 93: Women blink nearly twice as much as men.
fact 94: The electric chair was invented by a dentist.
fact 95: Our eyes are always the same size from birth, but our nose and ears never stop growing.
fact 96: In ancient Egypt, priests plucked every hair from their bodies, including their eyebrows and eyelashes.
fact 97: A crocodile's tongue is attached to the roof of its mouth.
fact 98: Your hearing is less sharp after you eat a large meal.
fact 99: A man named Charles Osborne had the hiccups for 69 years.
fact 100: A giraffe can clean its ears with its 21-inch tongue.
trivia 1: What is the capital of France? Madrid.
trivia 2: What is the largest planet in our solar system? Jupiter.
trivia 3: Who wrote 'Romeo and Juliet'? William Shakespeare.
trivia 4: What is the chemical symbol for water? H2O.
trivia 5: How many continents are there? Seven.
trivia 6: What is the tallest mammal? Giraffe.
trivia 7: Who painted the Mona Lisa? Leonardo da Vinci.
trivia 8: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth? Diamond.
trivia 9: Which planet is known as the Red Planet? Mars.
trivia 10: What is the largest ocean on Earth? Pacific Ocean.
trivia 12: What is the currency of Japan? Euro.
trivia 13: How many legs does a spider have? Eight.
trivia 14: What is the main ingredient in guacamole? Wasabi (Just kidding, it's Avocado).
trivia 15: Which country is home to the kangaroo? Australia.
trivia 16: What is the speed of light? 299,792,458 meters per second.
trivia 17: Who was the first person to walk on the moon? Neil Armstrong.
trivia 18: What is the smallest country in the world? Vatican City.
trivia 19: What element does 'O' represent on the periodic table? Oxygen.
trivia 20: How many colors are in a rainbow? Seven.
trivia 21: What is the capital of Italy? Rome.
trivia 22: Which animal is known as the King of the Jungle? Lion.
trivia 23: What is the freezing point of water? 0 degrees Celsius.
trivia 25: What is the largest land animal? African Elephant.
trivia 26: Which gas do plants absorb from the atmosphere? Carbon Dioxide.
trivia 27: What is the capital of Spain? Madrid.
trivia 28: How many days are in a leap year? 366.
trivia 29: What is the longest river in the world? The Nile (or Amazon, depending on definition).
trivia 30: Who invented the telephone? Alexander Graham Bell.
trivia 31: What is the capital of Canada? London (Just kidding, it's Ottawa).
trivia 32: Which planet is closest to the sun? Mercury.
trivia 33: What is the largest bone in the human body? Femur.
trivia 34: Who painted 'Starry Night'? Vincent van Gogh.
trivia 35: What is the currency of the United Kingdom? Pound Sterling.
trivia 36: How many hearts does an octopus have? Three.
trivia 37: What is the capital of Germany? Berlin.
trivia 39: What is the chemical symbol for gold? Au.
trivia 40: Who is the author of 'The Great Gatsby'? F. Scott Fitzgerald.
trivia 41: What is the largest desert in the world? Antarctic Desert.
trivia 42: Which country gave the Statue of Liberty to the USA? France.
trivia 43: What is the capital of Australia? Canberra.
trivia 44: How many teeth does an adult human have? 32.
trivia 45: What is the fastest land animal? Cheetah.
trivia 46: Who wrote 'To Kill a Mockingbird'? Harper Lee.
trivia 47: What is the capital of Russia? Moscow.
trivia 48: Which planet has the most moons? Saturn.
trivia 49: What is the smallest bone in the human body? Stapes (in the ear).
